June 29, 1997: Fiction
PLUM ISLAND, by Nelson DeMille. (Warner, $25.) A detective probes the murder
of a Long Island couple who may have been involved in germ warfare research.
THE PARTNER, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $26.95.) The pursuit of $90 million
stolen by a lawyer who apparently died but is actually hiding in Brazil.
THE PRESIDENT'S DAUGHTER, by Jack Higgins. (Putnam, $23.95.) The
President of the United States copes with kidnappers who threaten to kill his love
child.
OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $16.) The
problems of finding your way through life; in verse and pictures.
UP ISLAND, by Anne Rivers Siddons. (HarperCollins, $24.) An Atlanta woman,
after a bad marriage and her mother's death, seeks a new life on Martha's
Vineyard.
END OF THE DRIVE, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $15.95.) Eight previously
unpublished tales about the Old West.
PRETEND YOU DON'T SEE HER, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster,
$25.) A chance witness to a murder is obliged to live anonymously to save her life.
LONDON, by Edward Rutherfurd. (Crown, $25.95.) Two thousand years of life in
Britain's capital as seen through the eyes of six families.
FAT TUESDAY, by Sandra Brown. (Warner, $24.) A cop turned outlaw and the
wife of a sinister attorney go on a tear in New Orleans during Mardi Gras.
THE TENTH JUSTICE, by Brad Meltzer. (Weisbach/ Morrow, $23.) A young
Supreme Court clerk inadvertently reveals a forthcoming Court decision, severely
straining the loyalty and honor of his friends.
SNOW IN AUGUST, by Pete Hamill. (Little, Brown, $23.95.) The friendship of an
Irish Catholic boy and a Czechoslovak rabbi in Brooklyn during the late 1940's.
MASON & DIXON, by Thomas Pynchon. (Holt, $27.50.) The story of the two
British surveyors who drew the boundary between the North and the South in the
THE NOTEBOOK, by Nicholas Sparks. (Warner, $16.95.) A World War II veteran
meets an old flame who is about to be married.
LOS ALAMOS, by Joseph Kanon. (Broadway, $25.) As scientists work on the
atomic bomb in 1945, a Manhattan Project security officer is found murdered.
SECRECY, by Belva Plain. (Delacorte, $24.95.) The horrifying memory of a teen-
Non-Fiction
JUST AS I AM, by Billy Graham. (HarperSanFrancisco/Zondervan, $28.50.) The
autobiography of the crusading preacher.
INTO THIN AIR, by Jon Krakauer. (Villard, $24.95.) A journalist's account of his
ascent of Mount Everest in 1996, the deadliest season in history.
INTO THE STORM, by Tom Clancy with Fred Franks Jr. (Putnam, $27.50.) The
battle against Iraq during the gulf war as experienced by a general who
commanded armor and infantry.
ANGELA'S ASHES, by Frank McCourt. (Scribner, $24.) An Irish-American writer
recalls his childhood amid the miseries of Limerick.
THE BIBLE CODE, by Michael Drosnin. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) A journalist
contends that important events have been predicted in the Bible.
BRAIN DROPPINGS, by George Carlin. (Hyperion, $19.95.) Comments on life
and the ways of the world by the stand-up comedian.
THE DILBERT FUTURE, by Scott Adams. (Harper Business, $25.) Satirical
speculations, in words and cartoons, about what the 21st century holds in store.
WITHOUT A DOUBT, by Marcia Clark with Teresa Carpenter. (Viking, $25.95.)
The prosecution of O. J. Simpson as seen by the former deputy district attorney.
UNDERBOSS, by Peter Maas. (HarperCollins, $25.) Life in the Mafia as lived and
observed by Salvatore (Sammy the Bull) Gravano.
MIDNIGHT IN THE GARDEN OF GOOD AND EVIL, by John Berendt. (Random
House, $23.) The mysterious death of a young man in Savannah, Ga.
TWO GUYS FOUR CORNERS, by Don Imus and Fred Imus. (Villard, $29.95.) A
collection of photographs of the Southwest by the radio personality and his
brother, with brief comments.
CONVERSATIONS WITH GOD: Book 1, by Neale Donald Walsch. (Putnam,
$19.95.) The author addresses questions of good and evil, guilt and sin.
THE MILLIONAIRE NEXT DOOR, by Thomas J. Stanley and William D. Danko.
(Longstreet, $22.) An analysis of the lives of wealthy Americans.
THE ONLY WAY I KNOW, by Cal Ripken Jr. and Mike Bryan. (Viking, $22.95.)
The autobiography of the Baltimore Orioles player.
THE PERFECT STORM, by Sebastian Junger. (Norton, $23.95.) An account of
the nor'easter of 1991, focusing on a crew of fishermen from Gloucester, Mass.
